perambulating—Oh, woe to the walker who is compelled to drag himself up their steeps, those tiresome paved steeps,
those hard, unyielding, provokingly smooth flagstones, or to go thundering down, his rapidity increasing every instant, when he is once in for it lurching tremendously like a ship in a swell, jerk, jerk, jerking—Oh, facilis descensus Averni, sed sed;—Ay, there's the rub. The Hôtel de Bellevue at Brussels ought to have a belle vue for you might as well scale the crags of Gibraltar as storm the heights of the Hôtel de Bellevue; whence, for all the boast of its title, I never could discover more belle vue than a dusty square, some formal houses, and a few murky park trees.

We left Brussels on Wednesday morning for Waterloo; the sun beamed sweetly among the long trunks of the aged trees of the forest of Soigny; and their damp bark glistened dewily,—as it rose up taller and taller, branching off into the bending boughs, and slender spray, with the delicate foliage scattered through: here every leaf defined separately and clearly as you looked up to the broad sky; there in light, spready masses, par- tially concealing the long tapery trunks which retired back, farther and still farther, yet distinctly grouped, and those groups separated by the gleamy stream of yellow sunshine, which shone full on the sides of the swelling green grassy banks, then broken by the intervening hollows, then climbing again up the dewy moss and white trunks. It was exceed- ing beautiful; I could have fancied the glister of the bright bayonets changing, like starlight on a wavy ocean, among the retiring foliage of those ancient trees—I forgot how many long years had past by since that eventful day.

This is the field of Waterloo. The round hills of green pasture lay unbroken before me, without a single tree, except where, fax to the right, the rich forest country commenced again, breaking away in rounded masses, till lost in the blue of the faint horizon. All is peace now. Englishmen may feel proud on the field of Waterloo—perhaps I did; but there is something mingled with it—Poor Napoleon! The grass is very green on the field of Waterloo—it has grown from the dust of our bravest. Oh, tread on it softly!

div.p: In forming the persona J.R., Ruskin was influenced not only by literary and artistic sources, but also by living poets and artists whom he was fortunate to meet or correspond with during his conceptualization and composition of the "Account." These contacts became especially important as Ruskin was "brought forward" as a professional contributor to Friendshipʼs Offering (see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”). Two of these men present a striking contrast with one another—Samuel Rogers (1763–1855) and James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835). Ruskin also had some contact at this time with John Claudius Loudon (1783–1843).

The personae of Hogg and Rogers each exhibited multiple and even contradictory sides, and the Ruskins must have been selective about what aspects of these public figures they hoped to cultivate in the patronage of their precocious son. Respecting Hogg, the Ruskins thought of him in his role as the Ettrick Shepherd, who was romantically imagined as having received his call to poetry when he was shepherd in Ettrick Forest in the Scottish Borders, and who still resided in georgic retirement on his farm in the Yarrow Valley. The Ruskins would have played down Hogg's colorful and risqué character in the “Noctes Ambrosianae” in Blackwoodʼs Edinburgh Magazine. This side of Hogg appealed to the Brontë siblings, who imitated the bravado and swagger of these dialogues in their own collaborative and competitive writing, but Ruskin's parents would hardly have considered such a persona as an appropriate model for Ruskin's solitary and decorous authorship.

When the Ruskins first met Hogg personally in 1832, he was undertaking his first visit to the metropolis of London, where was lionized by London society. Hogg's introduction to the Ruskins came by way of the community of expatriate Scottish literati in London who surrounded the publishing firms of John Murray and Smith, Elder. The latter, in particular, as the publisher of Friendshipʼs Offering, served as the hub for these connections: Hogg as a contributor to the annual; Thomas Pringle (1789–1834), as editor, and longtime friend of Hogg; and even Ruskin's cousin, Charles Thomas Richardson (1811–34), as a shopboy with the firm, who was the first to present Ruskin with a copy of Friendshipʼs Offering (probably the 1829 or 1830 volume, both of which contained contributions by Hogg).

Rogers, in sharp contrast with Hogg, was the urbane "man of taste," whose townhouse in St. James Square was a showplace of exquisitely curated Regency neoclassicism, and the scene of his famous breakfasts in which Rogers acted the part of social arbiter of the current London artistic and literary scene. In his most positive light, Rogers might have appeared to the Ruskins as a splendid embodiment of John James's tastes and aspirations. A former associate of Byron, and a habitué of at least the byways of fame, Rogers had earned a sound reputation for his topographical poem, Italy, which may have paled in comparison to the popular glare of Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage, but which was respectably and approachably neoclassical--regular in its versification, and grounded in the tradition of the Grand Tour to Italy. Rogers was also, like John James, a successful businessman, having made his fortune in banking; and even though he lavished extravagant sums on artists, engravers, and printers in order to satisfy his perfectionism in crafting editions of his poetry, Rogers recouped his huge investment in his illustrated edition of Italy and profited handsomely by its unprecedented sales. The unattractive side of Rogers was his notoriously acid wit and his worldliness at a time when middle-class Evangelical earnestness was turning the tide on the influence of Regency "men of taste."

The two writers also differed profoundly in taste. Rogers was so committed to his neoclassicism that Turner reined in his apocalyptic manner typical of his other works of the period in favor of a style that would harmonize with Rogers's restraint, by using less dramatic perspective in his vignette designs for Italy (Holcomb, “Neglected Classical Phase of Turnerʼs Art”). The artist whom Hogg most admired and hoped to secure as illustrator for his grandest gift book, a deluxe edition of The Queen's Wake, was John Martin (1789‐1854)--the artist who, ever far from restraining the apocalyptic, made his career by exploiting such subjects for their most histrionic theatricality and scale (All too typically for the hapless author, and despite generous subscription donations by John James Ruskin and others, Hogg's deluxe edition was never produced owing to disruptions in trade caused by Reform agitation in 1832; see OʼHalloran, “Illustrations to The Queenʼs Wake”, c‐civ.)

Of the two relationships, the Ruskins' contact with Hogg is the best documented (see James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835)). Their apparent preference for the Ettrick Shepherd's advice about Ruskin's future as a poet, when the youth was laboring over the MS IX fair copy of the "Account", may be no accident. Compared to Rogers, Hogg may have seemed hapless in his fortunes: his London venture ended in him foolishly mislaying his trust in an under-financed publisher, who went bankrupt and squandered the opportunity to produce a collected edition worthy of the author, whereas Rogers boasted the means to encase his writing in increasing splendor. (In 1834, when John James wrote to Hogg about John's "promise of very considerable talent," Rogers followed up the success of his 1830 Italy with an edition of his collected Poems, likewise illustrated by Turner, Stothard, and others, which the Athenaeum declared to be a "volume which, for true elegance and pictorial fancy, is unequalled, in an age remarkable for its love of splendid books" [Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 274; Piggott, Turnerʼs Vignettes, 39].) Nonetheless, when writing to Hogg, John James sounds pointed in addressing Hogg as a man “of talent and of heart,” as compared with “the world at large,” which lacks “comprehen[sion] . . . patience . . . feeling . . . delicacy,” suggesting that he trusted the humble Scottish "shepherd" over the urbane man of taste (Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 274).

Despite John James's sentiments, both Rogers's successes and Hogg's disappointments were endemic to a period of transition between publishing in the age of Scott and the more entrepreneurial and innovative, yet also volatile and confusing print culture in the age of Dickens. In a time when critical discourse commonly bemoaned the decline of poetry in unpropitious circumstances (Bristow, “Introduction,” Victorian Poet, 4-5), both Rogers and Hogg appreciated how poetry could gain new life from its relation with the visual arts--a relation that was rooted in tradition reaching back to the humanist dialogue or paragone between the sister arts, yet that was also undergoing renewal and transformation by mass-market print technologies. Both men shrewdly exploited the changes in print technology that created new venues and audiences for literature and art, such as the annuals and other illustrated books (on Hogg's enterprising approach to these venues during an otherwise depressed period in literary publishing, see Currie, introduction to Hogg, Contributions to Annuals and Gift‐Books, xix-xxxii; and for his appreciation of the fine arts--particularly modern painting, for its connection with literature and its accessibility to ordinary people--see Hughes, “Hogg, Art, and the Annuals”).

The sole anecdote to survive concerning Ruskin's audience with Rogers can be read in terms of commonalities shared by these mentors in the literary and artistic culture of the 1830s. We have no contemporary documentation of Ruskin's introduction to Rogers under Pringle's wing, other than evidence of Pringle's regular entrée to St. James Place (see Vigne, Thomas Pringle, 192). Ruskinʼs later story about his supposed contretemps of "congratulating . . . [Rogers] with enthusiasm on the beauty of the engravings by which his poems were illustrated," indicating that the youth knew “more of the vignettes [in Italy] than the verses,” and the chiding of Pringle "that, in future, when . . . in the company of distinguished men, . . . [he] should listen more attentively to their conversation" evokes a bygone era that valued polite conversation and dilettantish colleccting (Ruskin, Works, 34:96, 35:93). Yet, while Ruskin fits the anecdote into what he now regarded as his fatuous beginnings as a poet, his misplaced complements to the illustrator proves him to have been a boy of his decade, who had so carefully studied the visual culture represented by Rogers's Italy as well as by Prout's Facsimiles. (While we do not know when Ruskin's introduction to Rogers occurred, it is a reasonable guess that Pringle secured an audience on the strength of the youth's precocious achievement in the MS IX fair copy of the “Account”.)

In the mentoring of J.R., perhaps the most important qualification is indicated by a word dropped in the only mention of a publication by John to survive in the family correspondence of 1834. In a verse letter to his father dated 10 March 1834, Ruskin mentions--not Pringle and Friendshipʼs Offering--but John Claudius Loudon (1783–1843), the editor of botanical, landscaping, and other natural history publications. A key is that Ruskin regarded Loudon as a "friend" of the family: “To Mr Loudon, as a friend, / By way of some communication, / Some kind of little lucubration / On any sort of observation, / Among the Alps, you know, / On Micaslate, or any slates, / Granite, and gold, or toads and snakes, / I think that I shall make a show” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 285). Ruskin was alluding to his geological notes--dated March 1834, but published later that yea--in Loudon's Magazine of Natural History, "Enquiries on the Causes of the Colour of the Water of the Rhine", and "Facts and Considerations on the Strata of Mont Blanc, and on Some Instances of Twisted Strata Observable in Switzerland". One is struck by the apparent anomaly that the one forthcoming publication to merit Ruskin's attention--if he was as yet apprised of his other firsts for this year, the poetry commissions for Friendshipʼs Offering--were these geological observations, and later in life Ruskin would find it convenient to stress his keenness of factual observation at the expense of his poetic effusion. Again, however, one can perceive commonalities. Loudon, like Pringle and Hogg, was a Scot--a member of the extended "family" of Scottish literati in London who surrounded the boy wonder, many of whom visited Herne Hill in the 1830s. Loudon's publications also depended on the thriving visual culture of illustrated books and magazines during the period, and they were perhaps not too distant from the poetry anthologies in their communal appraoch, inviting amateurs to contribute to forums such as the Magazine of Natural History and trade “lucubrations” that did not necessarily depend on professional status.

Signs of havoc caused by the July Revolution in France and the Belgian Revolution of 1830 were still being marked six years later by Murrayʼs Hand‐book for Travellers on the Continent; and decades later, Ruskin would contrast Proutʼs quietude of manner with the state of medieval French architecture “such as her vestiges remained after all the wreck of revolution and recoil of war had passed over them” (Ruskin, Works, 14:395). In the boyhood “Account,” although composed much closer in time to these events, Ruskin shows little consciousness of recent political history.

Ruskin does comment in the “Account” on national identities, seeing Calais as “an introduction to France, and to the French,” but the narrator moralizes in non‐specific terms. On the road between Calais and Brussels, climbing to the top of Mont Cassel, the narrator points out the “fifteen battle‐fields” visible from the eminence that tell “a fearful tale of the ready ire of nations, yet looking as green and peaceful as if they had never been watered with blood.” Nothing is said about such signs of recent conflict as the destruction of the ancient Abbey of St. Bertin at St. Omer; rather, while the narrator, passing St. Omer, sneers at the “serpent folds” of “Romes religion” supposedly lurking beneath a religious procession, the English anti‐Catholic sentiment associated with that place was as old as the Gunpowder Plot—the Jesuit College at St. Omer having been implicated in that history.

Similarly out of touch is the poemʼs passage through France to Belgium and the neglect of any commentary on the Belgian character. The Belgian Revolution of 1830 had established the Kingdom of Belgium as a state separate from the United Kingdom of the Netherlands. English attitudes to the new kingdom—as Pieter François finds, examining such popular sources as travel guidebooks—were initially divided along party lines, with Whigs approving the Catholic revolutionaries and Tories supporting the Protestant Dutch kingdom (Murrayʼs 1836 Hand‐book remained staunchly Tory). Over the course of the 1830s, however, British opinion unified around a myth of Belgium as a “little Britain” that shared a royal connection in Belgiumʼs King Leopold I, and that supposedly had copied its neighborʼs constitutionalism and rising industrialization, and that even harbored, the English convinced themselves, a “hidden” protestantism beneath the nationʼs Catholic national identity (François, “British Views on Belgium”, 663–64). Yet Ruskinʼs impressions of Belgium, as given in the “Account,” do not reflect the partisan Tory views that Murrayʼs Hand‐book would advise to tourists, condemning the Belgians for lacking the “heroic patriotism” and “high‐minded courage and ceaseless perseverence” of their Protestant Dutch neighbors and for possessing “a coarseness of manners” and “debasement of the national character” (Hand‐book for Travellers on the Continent, 78). Nor do any of Ruskinʼs remarks appear to share in the myth of the Englishness of the Belgian character.

USE FOR GERMANY AND THE ALPS===========Other works acquired by the family both return in autumn 1833, and during John James Ruskinʼs ongoing composition of the “Account” in 1834, John James continued to acquire travel publications typical of this eclectic, transitional period. There were travel accounts written in the immediate post‐Waterloo period by Vicomte François René de Chateaubriand (1768–1848) and by William Stewart Rose (1775–1843), an associate of Byron and Rogers.John Jamesʼs account book does not identify the titles of these works, but Van Akin Burd suggests Chateaubriandʼs Souvenirs d₼Italie, d₼Angleterre, et d₼Amérique (1815) and Roseʼs Letters from the North of Italy (1819). There was also a “P. Rhine” (perhaps Pilgrims of the Rhine, a decidedly eclectic work by Edward Bulwer‐Lytton [1803–73], published in this year). For his birthday in February 1834, Ruskin received two works on Alpine travel: one, a work by Horace‐Bénédict de Saussure (1740–99), whose writings combined travel narrative with scientific observation of the Alps; the other, Illustrations of the Passes of the Alps by William Brockedon (1787–1854), who combined his talents as both an artist and scientist with travel writing and illustration. Ruskin wrote to his father that Brockedonʼs engravings in the Illustrations carried him “again over the summits of the higher Alps, over the winding paths of Splugen, and the glaciered crest of the Simplon, and the summmer snows of the St Bernard, and the lovely plains of gentle Italy” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 278; and see 286 n. 1 for John James Ruskinʼs 1833–34 lists of book purchases).
or the much larger, full‐page lithographs by Prout for the Facsimiles—but more commonly he invented the scene but realized his idea stylistically in the manner of Prout or Turner or Stothard.

Ruskin advances his “Account” from a travelogue poem in the eighteenth‐century topographical tradition, to a work reflecting the material culture of ekphrastic, topographical, and travel‐related publishing in the 1830s.

Walton's take on Ruskin's early art education as reflected in the "Account" is based on Ruskin's comic assessment in Praeterita of his abilities in โcopyingโ engraved illustrations with such โgreat,โ and โto most people now incredible, exactness,โ his obsessiveness not only prevented the project from completion, but also feminized his formation of self. Gifted with โso little original faculty,โ he lagged behind his cousin, Mary Richardson (1815–49), in โfree-hand copying,โ so that, far from developing a viable persona, he ventured outside Herne Hill only to be โtreated [like] a girlโ when he attended day school (Ruskin, Works 35: 81, 74-75, 77, 83).

Nord‐Pas‐de‐Calais and Belgium. These are among the northern Continental sites that Prout brought to British attention in the 1820s and 1830s. (Proutʼs even more far‐flung destinations in Eastern Europe, such as Prague, which he depicted in the Facsimiles and exhibited in watercolors at the Old Water Colour Society, found little success with the public.)

Proutʼs role in this transition in taste remains an emphasis even in Ruskinʼs later writing about the artist. Despite Ruskinʼs changing purposes over the years, his writing on Prout always refers back to the artistʼs discovery of northern Europe as a distinctive accomplishment in these earlier decades. For example, in Ruskinʼs 1849 article on Prout for the Art Journal, he does characterize the artistʼs first tour of northern Europe in terms of conversion and destiny, a preoccupation of Ruskinʼs in the 1840s: “the painterʼs vocation . . . fixed from that hour,” the “first effect upon his mind was irrepressible enthusiasm, with a strong feeling of a new‐born attachment to Art, in a new world [in northern Europe] of exceeding interest.” While in keeping with the concerns of The Seven Lamps of Architecture as well as of The Stones of Venice—situating Proutʼs personal discovery of vocation within a larger cultural history framed by a critique of misguided modernist feeling (Prout becoming “the interpreter of a great period of the worldʼs history, of that in which age and neglect had cast the interest of ruin over the noblest ecclesiastical structures of Europe, and in which there had been born at their feet a generation . . . which understood not their meaning” and which would destroy those structures, in Ruskinʼs view, by way of “resoration” [Ruskin, Works, 12:311, 314])—the core of the 1849 argument is built around his youthful experience of Proutʼs discovery of Flanders.

Likewise, in Ruskinʼs 1879–80 Notes on Prout prepared to accompany his loan of drawings for exhibition at the Fine Art Society, Ruskinʼs experience of Prout in the 1830s remains preserved in yet a later purpose, which is now to hearken autobiographically to his youth spent with his father in regular attendance at the Old Water Colour Society. There, Ruskin alleges, Proutʼs discovery of northern Europe earned the artist “by common and tacit consent” the “privilege . . . to introduce foreign elements of romance and amazement into this—perhaps slightly fenny—atmosphere of English common sense” that was typical of the homelier subjects of other artists (Ruskin, Works, 14:390). This later characterization from Ruskinʼs last decade of writing comes closest to Praeteritaʼs presentation of the role of Proutʼs Facsimiles as prompting the familyʼs “amazed” sudden departure for this romantic travel starting in northern France and Belgium (Ruskin, Works, 39:79). Like the 1849 essay, however, the 1879–80 Notes retain the youthful experience of wonder and exotic discovery outside the traditional Grand Tour, which Proutʼs lithographs opened up for British viewers in the 1830s.

SHOULD BE USED UP:
If this second stint of draft related to the "Account" in MS VIII suggests as well as in the preceding stint, which contains only draft "Account" (see MS VIII: Contents, b.1), Ruskin focused largely on poetry and prose chronicling the lower Rhine journey, the crossing of the Alps, and the Italy and Switzerland tour--writing that he fell short of incorporating into the MS IX fair copy beyond a partial account of Heidelberg, which stops in mid-sentence. On evidence explained in Composition and Publication, Ruskin commenced the first of these two stints around the date of his 8 February 1834 birthday. The entirety of the draft of the "Account" in MS VIII, therefore, substantial in volume and substance as that draft is, can be narrowed to between February and April. Since, near the end of the second stint, Ruskin was composing poetry on Ehrenbreitstein and Heidelberg, we can conjecture also that his fair copying in MS IX was keeping pace with his draft, and that he abandoned both aspects of the project at the same time, although it is possible that he continued to fair-copy after the time of any extant draft.

Judging by the sequence of prose and poetry “Account” sections contained in MS VIII, one can glimpse Ruskin as farther behind in fair-copying when starting this draft in MS VIII than when he ended, the two aspects of the project gradually converging before he broke off the "Account" to take up "Saltzburg." Near the beginning of the draft, he composed the prose sections for “Andernacht” and for “St. Goathr,” (the prose sections corresponding to the two poems selected for publication as “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” in Friendship's Offering, although the occurrence of the prose does not necessarily provide a clue as to when he composed or revised the poems for the annual). In MS IX, the prose sections on “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” fall approximately two‐thirds of the way into the work as fair‐copied. Ruskin cannot have carried the fair copy so far in early February, however, since mixed with the Rhine, Alpine, and Italian related writing in this first MS VIII stint is prose (but not the corresponding poems) describing the Belgian and earlier Rhine stages--prose on “The Meuse,” Cologne, and “Brussels,” in that order. In MS IX, these prose pieces fall roughly one‐third of the way into the fair copy, so it appears that in February Ruskin was catching up the composite-genre fair copy by drafting prose to complement poems on the Belgian tour that he had already composed (in MS IA, g.1). Assuming that Ruskin already had MS IX underway, the fair copy at this point would have contained the poems, prose, and perhaps drawings on Calais, Cassel, and Lille. Over the next three months, while continuing to compose writing related to crossing the Alps and beyond, Ruskin appears to have brought the fair copy in pace with ongoing, intermittent draft relating to the Rhine. Of this draft, the only poems are those on “Ehrenbreitstein” and “Heidelberg”, which fall within approximately the last quarter of the “Account” so far as fair-copied.

As already mentioned, the all-verse version of the "Account" represented by MS IA, g.1, could date from as early as the 1833 tour itself, but that manuscript can date no later than the MS IX fair copy (which incorporates textual revisions in the MS IA version) of the opening three sections, on Calais, Cassel, and Lille, which must have been underway by the first half of February when Ruskin composed the prose section on Brussels in MS VIII. Since the other "Account" manuscript bound in MS IA--the folded sheet, g.2--contains draft of prose for "Calais" along with draft of the poems for “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” (as well as sample representing Italy, the poem on "Milan Cathedral"), one can interpret this manuscript as representing a transition from the all-verse to the composite versions of the "Account," starting with the prose added to the project's opening poem--"Calais," which John James and John composed jointly, on evidence of the draft in MS IA, g.1. The draft in g.2 of the poems on “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” correspond to the versions of those poems as fair-copied in MS IX, and not as revised for Friendship's Offering; and since draft of the prose sections on those two sites fall so close to the start of the MS VIII draft, one might hazard that Ruskin's reconception of the genre of the work, along with the start of its fair-copy realization in MS IX, occurred not long before the onset of the MS VIII "Account" draft in February 1834--perhaps in December 1833, as a New Year's suprise for John James--but no firm evidence establishes when or how the transition came about.
div.head: Editorial Approaches to the “Account”
div.p: As traced in Publication, the publishing history of the “Account” might be viewed as a gradual recovery and conjectural reconstruction of Ruskinʼs final intentions for his elaborately composite‐genre, albeit uncompleted MS IX fair‐copy version. To see the editorial history in this teleological light assumes, however, that each of Ruskinʼs editors projected a similar ideal text. While all of these editors--Pringle, Harrison and Ruskin's father, Collingwood, and Cook and Wedderburn--did presumably have access to sufficient evidence of Ruskinʼs largest ambitions for the project—his composite‐genre version—their respective treatments suggest differing views about a preferred ideal text. The differences were partly dependent on the varying constraints of the publication venues. Friendshipʼs Offering, as a literary and artistic annual, was meant to anthologize only brief lyric poems or tales, whereas the Library Edition aimed at unprecedented completeness in collecting Ruskinʼs works. More fundamental than these contraints, however, was a question of what constituted an ideal or appropriate public text of the “Account”.

Initially, in terms of authorial intention and audience, and therefore of perceived ideal text, Ruskin and his editors worked at cross purposes. In the study of modern manuscripts, Donald Reiman has argued for the importance of distinguishing between a manuscriptʼs status as public, private, and confidential—a distinction that depends, “not [on] its degree of [rhetorical or aesthetic] artfulness or the level of personal intimacy between the writer and its readers but the nature and extent of the writerʼs intended audience. A manuscript is private if its author intended it to be read only by one person or a specific small group of people whose identity he knew in advance; confidential if it was intended for a predefined but larger audience who may—or may not—be personally known to or interested in the author; and public only if it was written to be published or circulated for perusal by a widespread, unspecified audience, including such abstractions as the nation, the reading public, and posterity” (Reiman, The Study of Modern Manuscripts, 65). In the case of the “Account”, Ruskinʼs audience was private, in that he expected his productions to be read primarily by his family, but also confidential, in that his parents shared his work with friends whose identity he could not predict. For example, Ruskin could not have predicted that samples of his verse composed (probably) for the “Account” would be read by the eminent writer, James Hogg, but John James took care in his letter prefacing the sample for Hogg to establish confidentiality: “Touching my son, there are many to whom I would never name him or his pursuits; but to men of talent and of heart I find I can say many things that I dare not tell the world at large. It cannot comprehend; it has not patience, nor feeling, nor delicacy” (Garden, ed., Memorials of James Hogg, 274). In writing the “Account”, Ruskin establishes the potential confidentiality of such an audience, not by any prefatory claims on the “heart” of the reader, but by imitating public status in a document whose immediate audience is private, his family; that is, in the MS IX fair‐copy version, Ruskin imitates the materiality of illustrated travel publications of the 1830s, the steel‐engraved Annuals and Other Illustrated Books, thereby rendering this version perhaps more confidential than the MS IA, g.1, version, which was a private collaboration with his father.

In editing poems from the “Account” as “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, Pringle replaced Ruskinʼs imitation with the actual conditions and rhetoric of a public production, while creating an illusion of the original work as less confidential than private in Reimanʼs terms. A “journal” belonging to “J.R.” seems mysteriously private in keeping with the nineteenth‐century cult of the personal, which, as Reiman remarks, led to a fashion for collecting autograph manuscripts (Reiman, The Study of Modern Manuscripts, 18–28). Thus the editor or editors—the extent of John James Ruskinʼs involvement in entitling or revising these poems is unknown—widen the supposed gap between public and private. On the one hand, in 1834 the general readers of Friendshipʼs Offering; and Winterʼs Wreath . . . for MDCCCXXXV, might have connected the title, “Fragments from a Metrical Journal”, with Byronʼs Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage; however, on the other hand, the text discourages a sense of the author as an “I,” having eliminated the prose pieces that affect an easy, confidentially personal tone, while revising the MS IX versions of “Andernacht” and “St. Goar” to achieve a sharper, more objective study in topographical contrast in their published versions. What Ruskin had produced as a confidential, imitatively “public” manuscript in the MS IX fair copy recedes—or seems to recede—into the privileged knowledge of the editor.

This sense of the editor as holding insiderʼs knowledge was enhanced by the publication of “Ehrenbreitstein” as “Ehrenbreitstein: Fragment from a Metrical Journal” in the privately printed and distributed Poems (1850). For many recipients of that volume, the title must have suggested merely that the editors were adding another “fragment” to the “Fragments from a Metrical Journal” that had so far been made public—if, indeed, the title meant even that much, given that the volume did not reprint the two poems that had formed the original “Fragments,” published sixteen years earlier. For readers to perceive this publication as more than just a compounding of fragments—rather, as a sophisticated reinstatement of a missing middle poem that, in Ruskinʼs MS IX fair copy, had bridged the two poems, which were later separated and published as a more severely contrasting pair in Friendshipʼs Offering—would have required a perceptive critical reading of the three fragments considered as a unit, a reading that would in turn have relied on a comprehensive knowledge of the textual history of the “Account”. Besides Ruskin himself, perhaps only John James Ruskin and W. H. Harrison possessed that privileged and knowledgable perspective. Since this edition was printed for private circulation, the editors were in a position to share their privileged knowledge with readers. Still, for many of the original recipients of the volume (as well as for the collectors who acquired copies later), “Ehrenbreitstein: Fragment from a Metrical Journal” would not have been perceived less as opening up an ideal text of the hitherto unknown portions of a “metrical journal,” than as testifying to a private and privileged story about the former omission of this “fragment.” As John James Ruskin wrote to Harrison, clarifying his intention regarding the audience of the 1850 collection, “the Book although apparently so is not intended to be anonymous in a Single Instance [i.e., of selections included in the anthology]. It is only denied the public” (Durham, 24 March 1850 [MSL 003/004/096], in Letters from John James Ruskin to W. H. Harrison, 1838–1853).

W. G. Collingwood situated himself in this tradition of the privileged editor, by virtue of his decision to restrict his 1891 edition to poetry, reserving an edition of early prose for a separate volume (see Ruskin, Poems [1850]). Now, the audience for the “Account” was again public, but inflected by the culture of rare book collecting, which created a new audience of eager and competitive consumers for rare copies of the 1850 Poems by “J.R.“ Thus, in one sense, Collingwoodʼs version maintains the tradition of allowing public access to only fragments from a private horde—so private that not even Ruskin himself, much less the collector privileged by mere cash to own the 1850 Poems, was “aware of the amount of material [for the “Account”] existing in rough copies at the back of . . . [Ruskinʼs] book‐shelves” (see Publication: 1891). In another sense, Collingwood could re‐frame the “Account” as a public work, available to an anonymous audience, since Ruskin had told its story in Praeterita. Collingwood signals this orientation by quoting long, contextualizing passages from the autobiography at the head of the poem and in his notes; and his his version of the text, which expands the verse selections to cover the full scope of the 1833 tour, serves as a poetic, documentary gloss on Ruskinʼs prose autobiographical narration of the masterʼs first significant experience of Continental landscape and towns. Yet, if Collingwood relies on the autobiography to authorize his version of a public text, his all‐verse version can claim only faulty authority relative to the manuscript “material . . . at the back of . . . [Ruskinʼs] book‐shelves,” for this version is not the young Ruskinʼs composite‐genre “Account”. Ironically, the manuscript that would have supplied some authorization for such a version—the all‐verse, and perhaps more private collaboration between Ruskin and his father, MS IA, g.1—was unknown to Collingwood.

Collingwoodʼs version therefore was a step toward an ideal text of Ruskinʼs original intentions for the “Account” only in a limited sense. As if jealous even of the public dimension that he afforded the work by constructing it as a tour poem illustrative of Praeterita, Collingwood substituted a new narrative in his 1894 biography, Life and Work of John Ruskin, suggesting that Johnʼs motives in making the work were furtive and separate from his fatherʼs interests, a closely held harbinger of Ruskinʼs mature mission in Modern Painters (see Hanson, “Ruskin in the 1830s”). This conception is almost the opposite of Ruskinʼs intention in his youth, which was to imitate a public work of his own time—an imitation of Rogersʼs Italy, as acknowledged in Praeterita—and which was meant to be confidentially shared with readers who qualified as “men of talent and of heart.” Thus, Collingwoodʼs version was a step toward restoration of Ruskinʼs original youthful project only in the sense that it provided an expanded framework, which Cook and Wedderburn could dramatically fill out with the poemsʼ missing complementary prose pieces, and with (at least) one reproduction of a hand‐illustrated page, along with footnotes describing the remaining drawings and where in the work they are placed. The Library Editionʼs version is the first genuine attempt at representing Ruskinʼs work as originally conceptualized. At the same time, Cook and Wedderburn inherited the agendas of their predecessors, and they too inevitably framed the work also as supplemental material illustrating Ruskinʼs autobiography.
